articles.headline: Costs and Tighter Rules Thwart Refinancings
articles.snippet: Interest rates are falling, but many potential borrowers may not qualify for the best rates.
articles.abstract: Interest rates are falling, but many potential borrowers may not qualify for the best rates.
articles.lead_paragraph: As mortgage rates hit new lows every week, the number of homeowners seeking to refinance their homes has spiked to its highest level in five years.

articles.headline: First Bailout Formula Had It Right
articles.snippet: Dealing with banks’ bad assets should be high on the list now. So how do we go about it?
articles.abstract: Dealing with banks’ bad assets should be high on the list now. So how do we go about it?
articles.lead_paragraph: “Blink,” the mega-best-seller by Malcolm Gladwell, is about the importance of first impressions, and Mr. Gladwell’s belief that “those instant conclusions that we reach are really powerful and really important and, occasionally, really good.” Case in point, it turns out, is the banking crisis. It sure looks like the government’s first impression about how to save the banks was the right one, after all.

articles.headline: Price Paid for Merrill Is Rising
articles.snippet: Shareholders are angry over Kenneth D. Lewis’s acquisition of Merrill Lynch, and the lawsuits are flying.
articles.abstract: Shareholders are angry over Kenneth D. Lewis’s acquisition of Merrill Lynch, and the lawsuits are flying.
articles.lead_paragraph: You could hardly blame Kenneth D. Lewis, the embattled leader of the Bank of America Corporation, for feeling a bit of buyer’s remorse.

articles.headline: Obama Presses for Quick Jolt to the Economy
articles.snippet: President Obama stepped into the effort to assemble an economic recovery package, seeking to quell criticism and to retain leadership on an initiative that could define his term.
articles.abstract: President Obama stepped into the effort to assemble an economic recovery package, seeking to quell criticism and to retain leadership on an initiative that could define his term.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Friday stepped squarely into the fractious effort in Congress to assemble an $825 billion economic recovery package, seeking to quell criticism from both parties and to retain leadership on an initiative that could define his term.
articles.byline: By Jackie Calmes and David M. Herszenhorn

articles.headline: Doing the Right Thing by Paying the Nanny Tax
articles.snippet: Consider a couple of reasons it may be wise for people who are not paying their housekeeper or baby sitter’s taxes to reconsider.
articles.abstract: Consider a couple of reasons it may be wise for people who are not paying their housekeeper or baby sitter’s taxes to reconsider.
articles.lead_paragraph: The nanny tax issue simply won’t go away.

articles.headline: New Rules on Doctors and Medical Firms Amid Ethics Concerns
articles.snippet: There are signs of an ethical makeover under way within the medical device industry, a field that has been troubled by the issue of undisclosed financial ties between companies and physicians.
articles.abstract: There are signs of an ethical makeover under way within the medical device industry, a field that has been troubled by the issue of undisclosed financial ties between companies and physicians.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the sun goes down in Las Vegas, steer clear of doctors.

articles.headline: Pfizer Said to Be Closing In on Deal for Wyeth
articles.snippet: The purchase of Wyeth by Pfizer for more than $60 billion could be completed over the weekend.
articles.abstract: The purchase of Wyeth by Pfizer for more than $60 billion could be completed over the weekend.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article was reported by Duff Wilson, Natasha Singer and Andrew Ross Sorkin and written by Mr. Sorkin.

articles.headline: Desperate Children Flee Zimbabwe, for Lives Just as Desolate
articles.snippet: Children are rushing across the South African border on their own in a journey made dangerous by thieves and rapists.
articles.abstract: Children are rushing across the South African border on their own in a journey made dangerous by thieves and rapists.
articles.lead_paragraph: MUSINA, South Africa  They bear the look of street urchins, their eyes on the prowl for useful scraps of garbage and their bodies covered in clothes no cleaner than a mechanic’s rags.

articles.headline: Firms That Got Bailout Money Keep Lobbying
articles.snippet: Pressing federal policy makers risks the appearance of recycling public money to advance a private agenda.
articles.abstract: Pressing federal policy makers risks the appearance of recycling public money to advance a private agenda.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The financial giant Bank of America says it is no longer lobbying the federal government about its unfolding bank bailout. After receiving $45 billion in bailout money, lobbying was just too unseemly.
articles.byline: By David D. Kirkpatrick and Charlie Savage

articles.headline: Obama’s Partisan, Profane Confidant Reins It In
articles.snippet: Rahm Emanuel is reconciling his fiery, bombastic ways with the cool and deliberate style of Obama World.
articles.abstract: Rahm Emanuel is reconciling his fiery, bombastic ways with the cool and deliberate style of Obama World.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Early this month, Barack Obama was meeting with the House speaker, Nancy Pelosi, and other lawmakers when Rahm Emanuel, his chief of staff, began nervously cracking a knuckle.

articles.headline: Pope Reinstates Four Excommunicated Bishops
articles.snippet: Among the four reinstated bishops, one had stirred outrage with comments denying the Holocaust.
articles.abstract: Among the four reinstated bishops, one had stirred outrage with comments denying the Holocaust.
articles.lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY  Pope Benedict XVI, reaching out to the far-right of the Roman Catholic Church, revoked the excommunications of four schismatic bishops on Saturday, including one whose comments denying the Holocaust have provoked outrage.

articles.headline: Obama Plans Fast Action to Tighten Financial Rules
articles.snippet: Officials say they will make wide-ranging changes, including stricter federal rules for hedge funds, credit rating agencies and mortgage brokers.
articles.abstract: Officials say they will make wide-ranging changes, including stricter federal rules for hedge funds, credit rating agencies and mortgage brokers.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration plans to move quickly to tighten the nation’s financial regulatory system.

articles.headline: Bad Times Spur a Flight to Jobs Viewed as Safe
articles.snippet: There is a new allure around jobs likely to keep a person employed, at reasonable pay, through a prolonged downturn.
articles.abstract: There is a new allure around jobs likely to keep a person employed, at reasonable pay, through a prolonged downturn.
articles.lead_paragraph: After years of struggling to get their wages up, the nation’s workers are trying to find jobs that will simply last, at least through the deep recession.

articles.headline: The Talented Mr. Madoff
articles.snippet: After Bernard L. Madoff’s fraud arrest, two versions of his life story are emerging: the Wall Street statesman, and the high-finance charlatan.
articles.abstract: After Bernard L. Madoff’s fraud arrest, two versions of his life story are emerging: the Wall Street statesman, and the high-finance charlatan.
articles.lead_paragraph: TO some, Bernard L. Madoff was an affable, charismatic man who moved comfortably among power brokers on Wall Street and in Washington, a winning financier who had all the toys: the penthouse apartment in Manhattan, the shares in two private jets, the yacht moored off the French Riviera.
articles.byline: By Julie Creswell and Landon Thomas Jr

articles.headline: In Pakistan, Radio Amplifies Terror of Taliban
articles.snippet: Every night a Taliban leader addresses terrified residents of Swat on banned activities and names those killed for violations.
articles.abstract: Every night a Taliban leader addresses terrified residents of Swat on banned activities and names those killed for violations.
articles.lead_paragraph: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — Every night around 8 o’clock, the terrified residents of Swat, a lush and picturesque valley a hundred miles from three of Pakistan’s most important cities, crowd around their radios. They know that failure to listen and learn might lead to a lashing — or a beheading.
articles.byline: By Richard A. Oppel Jr. and Pir Zubair Shah

articles.headline: Time to Unravel the Knot of Credit-Default Swaps
articles.snippet: Credit-default swaps clearly played a role in this financial debacle, and it is crucial that they are part of the solution.
articles.abstract: Credit-default swaps clearly played a role in this financial debacle, and it is crucial that they are part of the solution.
articles.lead_paragraph: WITH a new administration in Washington, let us hope that there will be an interest in defining the origins of the financial crisis, its abettors and, most important, its resolution.

articles.headline: Green-Light Specials, Now at Wal-Mart
articles.snippet: Wal-Mart’s embrace of environmental initiatives has pulled much of corporate America, and consumers, along with it.
articles.abstract: Wal-Mart’s embrace of environmental initiatives has pulled much of corporate America, and consumers, along with it.
articles.lead_paragraph: IT was billed the Choice Meeting: a secret two-day conference in Arkansas in 2005 pairing Wal-Mart Stores, a symbol of scorched-earth global capitalism, with some of the nation’s most influential environmentalists. And it began with a zinger.
articles.byline: By Stephanie Rosenbloom and Michael Barbaro

articles.headline: At Davos, Crisis Culls the Guest List
articles.snippet: Politicians, not corporate titans, are poised to be the big draw at this year’s World Economic Forum gathering, as power shifts away from the free market.
articles.abstract: Politicians, not corporate titans, are poised to be the big draw at this year’s World Economic Forum gathering, as power shifts away from the free market.
articles.lead_paragraph: GENEVA  The titans of Wall Street no longer sit atop the magic mountain.

articles.headline: $200 Laptops Break a Business Model
articles.snippet: As consumers are finding ways to buy computers at a lower cost, high-margin businesses are hurting.
articles.abstract: As consumers are finding ways to buy computers at a lower cost, high-margin businesses are hurting.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  The global credit crisis may have caused the decline in consumer and business spending that is assaulting the giants of high tech. But as the dominant technology companies try to emerge from this slump, they may find themselves blaming people like David Title just as much as they blame Wall Street.
articles.byline: By Brad Stone and Ashlee Vance

articles.headline: Obama’s Order Is Likely to Tighten Auto Standards
articles.snippet: President Obama will direct regulators to move swiftly on an application by 14 states to set strict automobile emissions and fuel efficiency standards.
articles.abstract: President Obama will direct regulators to move swiftly on an application by 14 states to set strict automobile emissions and fuel efficiency standards.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Obama will direct federal regulators on Monday to move swiftly on an application by California and 13 other states to set strict automobile emission and fuel efficiency standards, two administration officials said Sunday.
articles.byline: By John M. Broder and Peter Baker

articles.headline: Hollywood Now Cast as Sensible
articles.snippet: Historically, media companies in New York have seen their Los Angeles-based divisions as wayward children. But now the pointed finger of reproach is going the other way.
articles.abstract: Historically, media companies in New York have seen their Los Angeles-based divisions as wayward children. But now the pointed finger of reproach is going the other way.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES

articles.headline: Pfizer Agrees to Pay $68 Billion for Rival Drug Maker Wyeth
articles.snippet: The deal creating a pharmaceutical giant is the first big merger backed by Wall Street in months.
articles.abstract: The deal creating a pharmaceutical giant is the first big merger backed by Wall Street in months.
articles.lead_paragraph: The board of Pfizer, the world’s largest drug maker, agreed to acquire a rival, Wyeth, for $68 billion, the companies announced Monday.
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Duff Wilson

articles.headline: Maliki Pushes for Election Gains, Despite Fears
articles.snippet: Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki of Iraq is trying to reassure Iraqis that he will respect local interests.
articles.abstract: Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki of Iraq is trying to reassure Iraqis that he will respect local interests.
articles.lead_paragraph: JANAJUH, Iraq — Few have as much to gain or lose from the provincial elections on Saturday as Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, whose party is battling rivals across Iraq.

articles.headline: OPEC Achieves Cuts in Output, Halting Price Slide
articles.snippet: Members of the oil cartel have slashed their output by more than three million barrels a day in recent months, temporarily stopping the slide in oil prices.
articles.abstract: Members of the oil cartel have slashed their output by more than three million barrels a day in recent months, temporarily stopping the slide in oil prices.
articles.lead_paragraph: After months of gradually closing the oil spigot, members of the OPEC cartel have managed to stop the slide in oil prices  at least for now.

articles.headline: From Hospital, Afghans Rebut U.S. Account
articles.snippet: Conflicting accounts of a raid on suspected insurgents underscore a rift between Afghans and American forces.
articles.abstract: Conflicting accounts of a raid on suspected insurgents underscore a rift between Afghans and American forces.

articles.headline: Melding Obama’s Web to a YouTube Presidency
articles.snippet: President Obama is trying to bypass the news media and take messages straight to the public.
articles.abstract: President Obama is trying to bypass the news media and take messages straight to the public.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Lyle McIntosh gave everything he could to Barack Obama’s Iowa campaign. He helped oversee an army that knocked on doors, distributed fliers and held neighborhood meetings to rally support for Mr. Obama, all the while juggling the demands of his soybean and corn farm.
articles.byline: By Jim Rutenberg and Adam Nagourney

articles.headline: Technology Gets a Piece of Stimulus
articles.snippet: President Obama’s economic recovery plan pours money into old-fashioned public works projects like roads and bridges, but it also has some ambitious 21st century twists.
articles.abstract: President Obama’s economic recovery plan pours money into old-fashioned public works projects like roads and bridges, but it also has some ambitious 21st century twists.
articles.lead_paragraph: The time-tested way for governments to create jobs in a hurry is to pour money into old-fashioned public works projects like roads and bridges. President Obama’s economic recovery plan will do that, but it also has some ambitious 21st century twists.

articles.headline: For $10, Fuld Sold Florida Mansion to His Wife
articles.snippet: The transaction between Richard S. Fuld Jr. and his wife, Kathleen, is likely to raise eyebrows for reasons other than the price.
articles.abstract: The transaction between Richard S. Fuld Jr. and his wife, Kathleen, is likely to raise eyebrows for reasons other than the price.
articles.lead_paragraph: Housing prices are falling around the country, but this one sounds hard to believe: A seaside mansion on Jupiter Island in Florida, bought for more than $13 million five years ago, was just sold for $10.

articles.headline: Nationalization Gets a New, Serious Look
articles.snippet: The White House is dancing around a delicate question: Is the president prepared to nationalize the banking system?
articles.abstract: The White House is dancing around a delicate question: Is the president prepared to nationalize the banking system?
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Only five days into the Obama presidency, members of the new administration and Democratic leaders in Congress are already dancing around one of the most politically delicate questions about the financial bailout: Is the president prepared to nationalize a huge swath of the nation’s banking system?
